931B0EA1228447F2B11248460B35EF95.description: Describe and provide examples of Newton’s three laws of motion in practical situations such as sports, flight and transportation.

7925AA13A5364023B35C8F0E973F19A1.description: Analyze student-collected data to verify the relationship between the acceleration of an object and the net force acting on it.

857D15B6BF2D46CCB11390DE0CF98F97.description: Provide examples of technologies that have been developed to increase or decrease frictional forces between two or more surfaces.

FF338F9D1E3D4B0C89B0C9664C2B0618.description: Demonstrate the role of friction in changing the position and/or motion of an object.

A059D94A88CF459DAB628DEFC73A3598.description: Add force vectors in one and two dimensions (i.e., collinear, non-collinear [perpendicular] and non-collinear [nonperpendicular]) using vector diagrams to determine the net force acting on an object. (

BD2E777D39544E2488001A83D985FFAE.description: Investigate the effects of applying constant forces to objects at rest and to objects moving at a constant velocity in a straight line.

B827BF7645874F1CB257CB6BF421C82F.description: Pose and refine scientific questions about the ways in which forces cause objects to move or change their motion.

EC4ABAD50A47423EBB6C29271551C961.description: Explore the relationship between force and motion for objects moving in one and two dimensions.

FED3F25C0D284EFC8F421553FEF9A11B.description: Value the role and contribution of science and technology in understanding phenomena that are directly observable and those that are not.

099C643139D740F9B1863D2994DB151D.description: Construct and analyze graphs (i.e., distance-time, positiontime, speed-time and velocity-time) that represent the motion of objects that undergo acceleration.

DA7174A7005E4361A4FD7ED7E6AC7109.description: Differentiate between the concepts of instantaneous and average as they relate to speed and velocity.

525C0DE7EB3F4DF5AA3EF2712372488D.description: Demonstrate the importance of converting measurements to the same units when solving motion problems.

B9701C96CDC440438B8581123E029B18.description: Apply the concept of ‘rate of change’ to operationally define speed, velocity and acceleration.

11A4A868E59048329D905BDC6B0CE890.description: Evaluate the relevance, reliability and adequacy of data and data collection methods, including identifying and explaining sources of error and uncertainty in measurements. (

B9B2DEDB550744E4A3F482FD91D7C430.description: Develop and carry out experiments to determine the properties of accelerated motion, including identifying variables to be tested, developing appropriate sampling procedures for data collection, collecting and recording data and analyzing data to generate conclusions.

6FEA8744186E4F47B4FB8D278B0B4443.description: Investigate and represent the motion of objects that undergo acceleration.

676B53BC834E4BC09E0C0FE0EB30BDC2.description: Solve problems related to the motion of objects that travel at a constant speed in a straight line. (S)

71FFE15EE1F4400EB89B9AEBAF441F13.description: Derive the relationship between speed, distance and time (i.e., ???? = ?????/ ????? ) and between velocity, displacement and time (i.e., ????? = ?????? /????? ) using student-collected data from objects undergoing uniform motion

869AFA57D559417592F214C3D25455FE.description: Describe quantitatively the relationship among distance, time and speed for everyday objects that undergo uniform motion.

AD9AF2692DFB4DA6B7890C2B876C3D6D.description: Construct and analyze graphs (i.e., distance-time, position-time, speed-time and velocity-time) using student-collected data obtained from objects undergoing uniform motion or through computer simulations.

7751BAA7F3DE4897845AEA77C41F7259.description: Discuss the importance of distinguishing between scalar (e.g., distance, speed and time) and vector (e.g., position, displacement, velocity and acceleration) quantities when studying motion

5A0E8BB58D68499B802E2E94E5EC8BD3.description: Design and carry out experiments to determine the properties of uniform motion, using technologies such as photogates, motion detectors, ticker timers and stopwatches to collect distance and time data effectively and accurately.

816B9EDEEAB54BF390542ADEBEA159F2.description: Construct scale diagrams of displacement vectors (i.e., collinear, non-collinear [perpendicular], and non-collinear [nonperpendicular]) to represent changes in an object’s position.

8ABC244F82D4424CAF12E5EDE5D999EE.description: Discuss the concept of ‘frame of reference’ in determining whether an object is in motion and in constructing representations of an object’s motion.

43A2C472654A4A89AE4A890BADF7A1FD.description: Provide examples of objects that exhibit, or appear to exhibit, uniform motion.

DF9509CF2522485996A11379ED255CA7.description: Investigate and represent the motion of objects that travel at a constant speed in a straight line.

CAB2A08019964C5783077CF159D76EED.description: Describe examples of Canadian contributions to science and technology in motion-related fields such as transportation, sport science or space science.

0F094E38254D437983523E628D9716E3.description: Evaluate the design and function of a motion-related technology using student-identified criteria such as safety, cost, availability and impact on everyday life and the environment.

5F6429B0F338487484E839C45715A1E9.description: Design, construct and evaluate a prototype of an object that meets a student-identified need related to motion.

324FBB8ABD034726884B3F067048EA6C.description: Evaluate the historical development of a motion-related technology, including the role of continued testing in the development and improvement of the technology.

E9965F1E9EAE4879AE2C77FAC759C6BC.description: Describe how motion that may appear imperceptible to humans (e.g., continental drift, subatomic particles, light, blood circulating and galaxies) can be measured using appropriate technologies.

AE230B571CD24B4EA34F349E307B0B7C.description: Create a representation of different types of motion and motionrelated technologies from various cultures, including First Nations and Métis

99E8426272EB4569A789E3661426EA33.description: Explore the development of motionrelated technologies and their impacts on self and society.

F57985134EB443C0947C9A041CF6F116.description: Force and Motion in Our World

E1413976FBCE493CA4D1C9B04A590C8C.description: Work co-operatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan, and troubleshoot problems as they arise when investigating rates of reactions.

84621F196E58415D8C07DAA19EB031BE.description: Research how the rates of chemical reactions are controlled in everyday situations as well as in agricultural and industrial applications.

08A7BEC89F62499F885ABB6217C058A1.description: Value the processes for drawing conclusions in science.

E3916612C8ED4618927285309507F508.description: Use the collision model to explain differences in chemical reaction rates.

6EBC8CBA6BFE410EA67BA854542A72B7.description: Reflect upon data collection and analysis procedures, and suggest improvements to increase precision and accuracy.

0E34A6B8E1784EDF853CE18FD5A42310.description: Interpret patterns and trends in data, and infer or calculate linear and nonlinear relationships among variables related to chemical reaction rates

6D01892E6FD54173BCB360AFC0962074.description: Compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation of data related to rates of chemical reactions.

98D7E1A18D9A4618A35F7A51B414E986.description: Design and perform an experiment to determine how various factors affect chemical reaction rates, including identifying and controlling major variables.

289F35FF07944302BFF60E28051BA0C1.description: Formulate scientific questions about the rates of chemical reactions and the factors that affect rates of chemical reactions.

F27477F723174B65A551EC61BB054C89.description: Predict how factors such as temperature of the reactant(s), concentration of the reactant(s), surface area of the reactant(s) and the presence or absence of catalysts or inhibitors might affect the rate of a chemical reaction.

420EE00445E04FC38B7EF1831B53ED1C.description: Provide examples of chemical reactions that occur over a range of time scales.

20A6CDC572F4430EBC4C3DF59072D269.description: Investigate the rates of chemical reactions, including factors that affect the rate.

0025CE750FF441C88728B564D238871F.description: Discuss the value of representing chemical reactions using models, word and skeleton equations and balanced chemical equations.

BB4ACF801BB04A57AB5EDB343C6EC481.description: Verify whether a chemical equation is correctly balanced, and correct any errors.

271FCCEC2D8C4289B233B67BD973C8AE.description: Categorize chemical reactions as synthesis, decomposition, combustion, single replacement and double replacement, including acid base neutralization.

5BA87BAB0A4440D38FF70D65F5F1039F.description: Differentiate between the use of subscripts and coefficients in representing the numbers of atoms and molecules present in chemical reactions

44057FF613E34D579AF057449ADDEDE8.description: Translate word equations to balanced chemical equations and balanced chemical equations to word equations.

5393B987DAE144EDAD245CB5B547AEA8.description: Represent chemical reactions and conservation of mass using skeleton equations and balanced equations.

D0B68B2148A343C39DDF4F2948F9CC94.description: Represent chemical reactions, organic compounds and conservation of mass using models and word equations.

83C66398F09349B6B57724F35FC2DFF8.description: Explain the importance of the concept of conservation of mass in understanding, interpreting and predicting results of chemical reactions.

7F58661C1A00431F99129FEF4725308D.description: Design and safely carry out an experiment to confirm the law of conservation of mass, identifying and controlling major variables.

1468A0F0526E4EF6BE6FCC9C4330B3F1.description: Represent chemical reactions and conservation of mass symbolically using models, word and skeleton equations and balanced chemical equations.

CB9E108BC1A94BC7A3E3B1ED929F177C.description: Explain the importance of scientific nomenclature systems such as the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) naming conventions in communicating information about chemical compounds.

294D8C7D647843FC9BC99D2D47C4842A.description: Name and write formulas for common acids and bases, using the periodic table, a list of ions and rules for naming acids and bases.

FDD6817A3DFF4B2CA6A9342A53BAD81D.description: Describe how the pH scale is used to classify substances as acidic, basic or neutral.

4070DA383E8E4E6F8A6BA74D1A10B81F.description: Investigate how certain substances, including those traditional to First Nations and Métis cultures, can serve as acid-base indicators.

EC79F7740A774EEC955F5D83FF1ED2F5.description: Classify substances as acids, bases or salts, based on observable properties, name and chemical formula.

A0FEEB436B76452EA186F0C06492AEFD.description: Design and carry out investigations to determine the properties of acids and bases, including selecting and using appropriate instruments for safely collecting evidence.

51DB990EF60F4733AF7712436B126CFF.description: Name and write formulas for common molecular and organic compounds (e.g., methane, propane, butane, octane, methanol, ethanol and glucose), using the periodic table and a list of numerical Greek prefixes.

0268F7BD1CCF4B92ACA291794327C67F.description: Relate the properties (e.g., solubility, conductivity in solution or gaseous form, high melting point and brittleness) of ionic compounds to their uses.

A8C3FD5CA92A4A7783AFA3781C4E0AB7.description: Classify substances as ionic or molecular, based on their properties and the results of student conducted tests (e.g., melting/boiling point, electrical conductivity and solubility).

238C4C7B44A041F4B3B21700421204AC.description: Analyze the relationship between the structure of ionic compounds, their chemical formulas and their common names.

9544112B44AD4C4DA36963203D08AC75.description: Name and write formulas for common ionic compounds, including compounds involving polyatomic ions, using the periodic table and a list of common ions.

29B0B43669C544FAA0C522DB89FA0BC7.description: Discuss the importance of valence electrons, and whether they are shared or transferred, in determining bond type in chemical compounds.

05F1E9AA29B14F97976C2E34EC26788E.description: Examine the relationship between an element’s position on the periodic table, the number of its valence electrons and its chemical properties.

149A6EEE503E42B68DEB553AEE5B77E8.description: Name and write formulas for common ionic and molecular chemical compounds, including acids and bases.

61F1BFBE72C3425A85A330ECC4791ED4.description: Research the operation of technologies designed to monitor and manage pH in various applications such as swimming pools, consumer products, agriculture and horticulture

C1A1D5E6798C4E368D380EFFDF9F179D.description: Provide examples of the importance of pH measurements in areas such as biology, chemistry, food science, environmental science and water treatment.

8EFD75EBA1494B838F323C9984E8BA44.description: Research practical examples of chemical reactions involving acids and bases, including neutralization reactions such as those involved in chemical spills, soda-acid fire extinguishers and antacids.

F3FB4CE595F1410AA650375DA8205CBF.description: Investigate the properties of endothermic and exothermic chemical reactions, including identifying where or how energy is absorbed or released in the reaction and identifying potential benefits and consequences of the reaction.

D43193CBB62F48549F09D25FBE47A722.description: Differentiate between reactants and products in chemical reactions.

F329BC02B02945E3AA8CEC8986585CB0.description: Explain why it can be difficult to classify changes as physical or chemical, including reference to the reversibility of the reaction.

11BDA6226C9042B9B1C5574C10C3CCFE.description: Demonstrate knowledge of Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS 2015) standards by selecting and applying proper techniques for handling and disposing of lab materials and interpreting Safety Data Sheets (SDSs).

0DF001449B534E97AE26B0E04C42769D.description: Observe and describe a variety of chemical reactions, including synthesis, decomposition, combustion, single replacement and double replacement.

C71C1362310344148F75D8606A886A1E.description: Research the ways in which people, including First Nations and Métis, from various times and cultures have applied their understanding of the transformation of materials to produce new substances

D0704E909DE2491480D8C86EE5C44F3C.description: Create a representation about the prevalence of chemistry in our lives.

E88EC007D3014420B8A846A6790BF73E.description: Explore the properties of chemical reactions, including the role of energy changes, and applications of acids and bases.

050115924D19495193F54EE79E433723.description: Analyze the interdependence between the water cycle and other biogeochemical cycles.

961557659D4E431CAE90514F161F4F80.description: Research the short-term and long-term effects of small-scale and large-scale agricultural practices on the cycling of phosphorus, nitrogen and other nutrients in an ecosystem.

121D012EC97D49838BDA31D316C1BE1C.description: Compare the processes of nitrification and denitrification in terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems

6D10F6B4C1B745E8B7FEF45EDD9A1FA0.description: Design and carry out an investigation to determine the effect of carbon dioxide levels on photosynthesis and/or to determine the effect of nitrogenous-based fertilizer on plant or algal growth. (

E527C09A1A374D318E70B6C0369F6297.description: Examine the role of photosynthesis, respiration and sinks in the cycling of carbon through the environment. (

FFE0B94AE615464484FC88DFA9E243A5.description: Describe how human actions can affect the cycling of matter and flow of energy through ecosystems.

2B13F7819DE04C5F95A52BA8D716BF5D.description: Explore Indigenous ways of understanding the role of matter and energy in the environment.

DF10FE7C9FC6494EB6A36636414B6111.description: Create a representation of a feedback mechanism that is relevant to a specific biogeochemical (e.g., carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and water) cycle.

F16D9A0B6E164CCA90ACBA9D1FC9275C.description: Explain systems in terms of their type (e.g., open, closed and isolated), equilibrium (e.g., dynamic, static, stable and unstable) and their associated feedbacks (e.g., positive and negative).

BDAA4E63EC87442CA531FD7A7CEC6BD8.description: Analyze how the bioaccumulation and biomagnification of human-made substances can affect the viability and biodiversity of organisms and populations in an ecosystem.

AAC105A06DC2446DAAC0774D8ED811C8.description: Examine how factors such as invasive species, habitat loss and climate change affect biodiversity within an ecosystem, and can result in species becoming at-risk (i.e., vulnerable, threatened and extirpated).

5C8225DCF1E74C8C92A7B1FAAD4437A8.description: Examine the relationship between the biodiversity of an ecosystem, its primary productivity and ecological resilience.

E99440AF519F46B39A90EBDE6667B5CE.description: Investigate various ways in which natural populations attempt to maintain equilibrium, and relate this equilibrium to the resource limits of an ecosystem with reference to concepts such as carrying capacity, natality, mortality, immigration and emigration.

981A2A2BF3F24A7FA32E27D5BBD7F518.description: Construct and/or interpret graphs of population dynamics of humans and other species to determine population trends within an ecosystem.

1DA918BEDBDF415381FF636F0C7F41E6.description: Examine ways in which scientists collaborate with Elders, knowledge keepers and other community members to gather and interpret data related to biotic components of ecosystems.

B482F1AEF05D4709AA756ABB17C058A5.description: Discuss ethical and cultural perspectives related to studying biotic components of ecosystems, including the potential benefits and consequences of technologies (e.g., radio collar) and techniques (e.g., mark and recapture) used to collect data.

A742CF826EDD4B2EB05834D9E11B993A.description: Determine the population density, percentage frequency and/or percentage cover of one or more organisms in an ecosystem using primary or secondary population data.

DE5C8559346443289E2DF681468C6556.description: Estimate the abundance of organisms in a local ecosystem using random (e.g., quadrat), systematic (e.g., line transect and belt transect) and/or stratified sampling techniques.

D2A0798AEF874D6D9B2F66E17EA69A69.description: Compare the biodiversity and climatic characteristics of several of Earth’s major biomes.

A936F83BDBA74A43BA7B77F9B374E6D8.description: Understand that scientists describe biomes as resulting from the interaction of biotic and abiotic factors such as temperature, precipitation, insolation, latitude, altitude and geography,

54DED335D7584897B481E3B08E197D8C.description: Discuss the importance of biodiversity and maintaining biodiversity.

239EFF26AC224973A5EB96CA18C51395.description: Examine biodiversity through the analysis of interactions among populations within communities.

56C3829121664A28B2B35F65FCD23433.description: Provide examples to show how scientific understanding may be refined in light of new evidence.

31CC47CE5C9442D3B471D0661D3A4A05.description: Provide examples of positive and negative feedback mechanisms in Earth’s climate system. (

C986418ED96E4CCBA7F7D67875D920E0.description: Analyze weather and atmospheric data to identify patterns in temperature and atmospheric pressure, and changes in those patterns locally, regionally and globally.

1B63A1572B104DE1B9A085ED8327F8FA.description: Examine how interactions between heat, pressure and the Coriolis Effect result in global wind patterns, ocean currents, jet streams and severe weather (e.g., hurricanes, tornadoes, blizzards and thunderstorms).

3193445AA52D4FCD9EDF5387CFECE93C.description: Investigate, through laboratory activities or simulations, heat transfer in air and water, including heat involved in phase changes.

C7BD16264B8544EBBD3F6E435BD30E10.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a model used to illustrate the natural greenhouse effect, the reflectivity of Earth’s surface or the relationship between Earth’s axial tilt and the seasons.

0A693855A801407DB95437851E7DAF51.description: Explain the role of natural sources (e.g., volcanoes, fire, evaporation and living organisms) of the primary greenhouse gases in Earth’s atmosphere and how they contribute to the natural greenhouse effect.

4FC6C4791C55400B92D1890C1408294F.description: Explain how greenhouse gases (e.g., water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, sulphur dioxide and ozone), particles, clouds and surface albedo affect the amount of solar energy absorbed and re-radiated at various locations on Earth.

961DE125B6494C3186BD00C587DC16A8.description: Hypothesize how energy transfer, weather and climate might be different if Earth had a different axial tilt, diameter, period of rotation and/or period of revolution.

F2C81D701FA54A03970FFBFCE84FFEB0.description: Investigate how Earth’s axial tilt, rotation and revolution around the sun cause uneven heating of Earth’s surface, resulting in global convection currents, the Coriolis effect, jet streams, thermohaline circulation of the oceans and climate zones.

2631176456B44BE1ACFB5D1A30A06293.description: Understand that Earth’s climate system results from the exchange of thermal energy and moisture between the sun, ice sheets, oceans, solid earth and the biosphere over a range of timescales.

5A165CAC383E4F6B891A455F1E826E34.description: Differentiate between weather and climate, and the impacts of each on daily life. (

019A497443FE412A92C7D07C3DA66A01.description: Investigate factors that influence Earth’s climate system, including the role of the natural greenhouse effect.

E39862135F574F27A2F5DAAA3678B24F.description: Assess the current and potential future effects of ongoing changes to Earth’s climate systems on the people and the environment in Saskatchewan and Canada’s Arctic region.

43992EF4DA3049E48AB2BE01EB49C56D.description: Develop, present and defend a position or course of action based on personal research related to mitigating the effects of global or local climate change or to enhancing the sustainability of an ecosystem, taking into account human and environmental needs

92CD8FDE73FD4288823E23067561207B.description: Reflect upon individual and societal behavioural and lifestyle choices that can help to minimize anthropogenic sources of global climate change

AE4C5F2227E2435F8715AF7DED3D2FD4.description: Research how scientists examine changes to the key indicators of climate change (e.g., CO2 concentration, global surface temperature, Arctic sea ice area, land ice mass and sea level) to support the scientific understanding of climate change.

F8B6B6B32DD343CEB1C6ACB8A75D6BB8.description: Provide examples of human actions that have contributed to the anthropogenic greenhouse effect.

CFAA70451BF6419BBF2544F60BDBAAA2.description: Select, integrate and analyze the validity of information from various human, print and electronic sources (e.g., government publications, community resources and personally collected data), with respect to sustainability, sustainable development and education for sustainable development.

A59589BDF30F4BE6B35CCC6AD1810CC3.description: Discuss why it is important to consider economic, social justice and environmental perspectives when examining sustainability.

5C98179AADC04C0D8B7F2E54D3319B78.description: Evaluate changes in the scientific worldview of sustainability and human’s responsibility to protect ecosystems, considering key milestones and publications such as Our Common Future, Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, Agenda 21, Convention on Biological Diversity and the Bonn Declaration.

C01947EE261045C9B75AB689433879EA.description: Examine the positions of First Nations and government agencies responsible for the stewardship and management of resources, including the duty to consult.

9A3971B4B1FD4D55A404F4A8AB70E4E2.description: Research how people from Aboriginal and other cultures view relationships between living organisms and their ecosystems, and the role of humans in those relationships.

BC8D6944A1CE4B65ADA2B0FC5368E8E7.description: Reflect upon your personal view of humanity’s relationship with the environment.

E1122ECCE9EC4A84BEE8CFA8CFE7FEC8.description: Pose questions or problems relating to the effects of human actions on global climate change and the sustainability of ecosystems that arise from personal research

C92EA53D0B1249C2A03FECA64973591E.description: Assess the implications of human actions on the local and global climate and the sustainability of ecosystems.

9D78E3BDAE6E44E0ADC037E356042819.description: Represent the range of career options available related to a specific branch or sub-branch of science

970E2597DF7F4FA39E46ABD5B41C6B5E.description: Identify how personal activities and interests relate to topics in secondary science curricula.

3EB5C3040CA04F828991F33E88351A97.description: Attend a science-related career fair and analyze career choices based on information gathered.

8AE8B988DA294AD0954463F36E445596.description: Research the educational qualifications of people engaged in science-related careers

B94AAB0945EE463AB73A2F9F01B012BD.description: Identify the ways in which professional societies and organizations provide support to those engaged in sciencerelated careers in Saskatchewan.

6C8CBC469827401796E5AC0BAC15ED28.description: Research the range of science-related programs offered by post-secondary institutions in Saskatchewan and across the country.

E2AE4002C9CB4879B0DAB6EE50CC1AA3.description: Develop a profile of a specific individual involved in a science career, addressing factors such as their educational and personal background, what drew them to their career, the focus of their work and their advice for others who wish to pursue a similar career

9F3646110F6844B492F8F2396A7B87AE.description: Explore the breadth of science-related work roles and who is engaged in those work roles in the community.

7CAA11B3668A48668EAD3CDFDA6EA1BD.description: Create a representation that demonstrates interrelationships between various branches and sub-branches of science.

B7FC16FA6E2C4CAEA0C3E5F0E745843A.description: Investigate career paths related to various branches and sub-branches of science.
